BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 15, 1915.

LAIR
PRICE, FIVE CENTS

HOPKINS LOSES TO HAVERFORD

UNIVERSITY TO MOVE THIS YEAR

ROOTERS TO MARCH IN PARADE 'VARSITY SUFFERS HARD LUCK

Pennsylvania Team Score Two Touchdowns and Win, 14 to 10—Brooks
and Hoffman Again the Stars.

All Departments, Excepting Chemistry,
to Take Up New Quarters at Homewood in October Plans Now
Complete.

Students and Alumni to March to Homewood Saturday—Full Band and
Special Decorations to Be
in Evidence.

Poor Officials at Haverford Largely Responsible for Loss of Game—Teams
Evenly Matched—Tackling and
Interference Improves.

It was definitely announced last
week that Johns Hopkins would be
at Homewood next fall. At present
it is not known whether the actual
moving will take place before or
after the session of the summer
school, but in all probability the
classes in the summer school will
be held in McCoy Hall.
All the departments, with the exception of that of chemistry, will
be at Homewood by October, 1916.
All plans for the chemical laboratory are complete, but the University has not the money at present
to erect a building as expensive as
the proposed laboratory. Estimates
were called for on this building, and
the bid most seriously considered
was for a $300,000 structure, but
last Monday it was learned that
the University had not accepted this
bid.
As the plans now stand, Gilman
Hall will house all the departments
that are now in McCoy Hall, and,
in addition, the biology laboratory
and the psychology department.
Biology will occupy a large part of
the basement of Gilman Hall, and
psychology will have the top floor.
The present Engineering Building will contain the electrical and
mechanical engineering departments
and also the physical laboratory.
Civil engineering, now in the Engineering Building, will, by next
fall, have a building of its own.
Work has been actively started on
the new home of the civil engineers. The new Civil Engineering
Building will also have the geology
laboratory until this department
gets a building of its own.
It would be impossible to move
the chemistry laboratory into any
of the other buildings at Homewood: so much special apparatus is
required that the proposition would
be exceedingly expensive. About
one-third of the expense of a new
chemistry building would be put
into specially constructed apparatus
and fixtures. Dr. A. R. L. Dohme
has offered, if several others will
assist him, to underwrite the interest for five years on a loan for the
erection of a new chemistry laboratory, but as yet no others have
shown an inclination to help Dr.
Dohme in his generous offer.
President Goodnow has talked
with Mayor Preston concerning the
purchase by the city of McCoy Hall
and the geological, chemical and
biological laboratories as an addition to the overcrowded City College. If the-University makes such
a sale the present physical laboratory will be used for a chemistry la-

For the first time since the memorable season of 1912, a monster
parade of the undergraduate students will be held before the football game with St. John's. The students will form in regular order,
according to classes, at McCoy Hall
on Saturday at 1.30 P. M., and
will proceed according to plans
which have not as yet been announced to the athletic field at
Homewood.
An effort will be made to obtain
permission from the city authorities
to have a steam roller at the head
of the procession and it is planned
to have a goat, suitably decorated,
to accompany the leaders of the
parade. The students will wear
regulation caps, in black and blue,
which will be obtainable from the
Athletic Association before the day
of the game. A full band will play
at the head of the parade during
the entire march. Class flags, alumni banners and all manner of decoration will be in evidence and no
effort will be spared to make the
effect as complete as possible.
A canvass of the entire University is being made to secure funds
to pay for the band and every student is expected to contribute fifty
cents. Representative members of
the four classes have been appointed
to collect the money, and all students are urged to hand in their
contributions as soon as possible, in
order to facilitate the work of the
committees.
Since the time of the game has
been set at 2.30 P. M., it has been
thought advisable to start the93,arade
at least an hour before that time,
in order to allow plenty of time for
an adequate demonstration. Participants are especially requested to
be on hand at least fifteen minutes
ahead of time, so that all arrangements may be successfully carried
out.

By COACH CHARLES E. BRICKLEY

The Black and Blue eleven met
defeat in its game with Haverford
Saturday, the score being 14 to 10.
Hopkins started by playing the
Pennsylvanians off their feet during the first quarter and scored ten
Points, but the enemy came back in
the latter part of the contest, holding the 'Varsity scoreless and gaining two touchdowns.
After the first kick-off, punts
were exchanged, and Hoffman and
Brooks carried the ball in a series
of runs to the 5-yard line, from
Which point Brooks carried it over
after three attempts through Haverford's line. Wilkinson kicked goal.
Brooks again figured in the scoring in this quarter, carrying the ball
on a 45-yard run to the 30-yard line,
from which Hoffman kicked goal.
There was no more scoring in the
quarter.
In the second period Haverford,
having the wind at its back, got the
better of the punting and scored a
touchdown from an on-side kick.
A disagreement arose as to the
validity of the play which .resulted
in this score. It was contended by
the Black and Blue that the backfield was off-side at the time of the
kick and was hence ineligible to recover the ball. However, the officials allowed the touchdown to
count. The Hopkins men allowed
the ball to roll, without touching it,
over the goal for what they believed
was a touchback, and were very
much disappointed to find that the
officials decided to allow the score
to count.
In the remainder of the first half
little was gained by either side.
Bowers ran a punt through a broken
field in a
hair-raising manner for
thirty-five yards, but the ball was
called back by the officials, who penalized the Black and Blue for holding. No more scoring was done in
this period.
In the next period, Haverford „
started out with different tactics,
using the forward pass to advantage
for a while,
but finally resorting to
kicking after Hopkins had broken
Up several
plays, and Darley
dropped a
punt on the 8-yard line
Which was recovered by Van Dam
and carried over
for Haverford's
second touchdown.
The fourth quarter brought forth
no especial gain for either side.
Forward passing was used throughout the period, but the ball remained
about in midfield most of the time.
The stars of the game were Hoffman and Brooks for Hopkins and
Van Dam and Moon for Haverford.
Schmidt and Ormond also excelled
(C9ntinued on page 8, col.- 2)

The game with Haverford was a
heart-breaking affair, both, from the
standpoint of the players and
coaches. The teams were evenly
matched, and the contest would
have been a wonder to watch had it
not been for the poor work of the
officials.
Never in all my experience in
football have I seen a game conducted as poorly as on Saturday.
And the unfortunate part of it all
was that the great majority of the
poor decisions counted against Hopkins—one of them resulting directly
in a touchdown on a so-called onside kick. The referee in particular was at fault time and again, and
it always seemed that Hopkins was
the team to suffer. There is certainly no disgrace in losing a football game to a team which plays
better football, and I should have
nothing but praise for our opponents if they outplayed us and won,
but I really feel that if the officials
had given us half a chance we
would have come out on top.
One of the most gratifying features of the game, from the coaches'
standpoint, was the improvement in
interference on the part of Hopkins.
For the first time this season opponents were really taken out of
the play. But even a greater improvement must be made if we are
to defeat St. John's and Maryland
Agricultural College.
The tackling on the part of Hopkins was very good. The men
tackled hard and clean, and there
were few missed tackles. The work
of the secondary defense was especially good in this respect. Haverford had a varied open attack which
was not easy to solve.
The breaks of the game nearly
all went to Haverford. Credit
should be given to them for taking
advantage of them. Hopkins is still

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 15, 1915.

MUSICIANS' WORK PROGRESSES

DR. HOWE ON "INCOMING ALIEN"

Y. M. C. A. OUTLOOK BRILLIANT

Glee and Instrumental Men Hard at
Work on Season's Music—Attractive Schedule Being Arranged.
More Men Needed.

New York Commissioner of Immigration
Says Number of Incoming Aliens
to Be Expected After War
is Uncertain.

Attendance at Chapel and Bible Classes
Improves Greatly - Mr. Hursey
Speaks at Luncheon— Officers
Pleased With Prospects.

The Musical Clubs have gotten
their work on the program for this
year under headway and are well
on the road to what will undoubtedly be a most successful concert season. The Glee Club has had several rehearsals, and although the attendance at some was not encouraging, those last held were as successful as the usual run of beginning
meetings. A large number of new
men are out for the club, and from
now on the work of the leader will
consist largely of picking out the
most likely candidates. All students who have in mind trying out
for the club should report at once,
while there is yet an opportunity
to catch up with the work.
The Instrumental Club began its
work with a good rehearsal on Friday night. The men from last
year's clubs were out in full force,
but few new candidates presented
themselves. The management desires to announce that since the
work of the Instrumental Club goes
along very rapidly, all candidates
who have not as yet reported should
do so at the next rehearsal, in order
to get in line before it becomes too
late. Flute, 'cello and clarinet players are especially needed.
Plans for a very full schedule are
being worked out by the management. The season will begin with
the first week in January and will
extend to the week after Easter,
taking in a large number of engagements in and about Baltimore, as
well as two or three trips of moderate length. Attention is again being called to the fact that outside
assistance in the work of arranging
trips is desired by the management,
and that five dollars will be paid
any student who works up acceptable plans for a trip.
The annual McCoy Hall concert
will be held in the latter part of
February. The exact date has not
yet been set, but will be chosen from
the latter two Friday nights—the
eighteenth and the twenty-fifth.
Especial attention will be paid the
work on this concert, and a particular effort will be made to enlist the
support of the undergraduates and
alumni to a greater degree than has
been attained in former years.
The management wishes to call
the attention of the undergraduate
students to the fact that they are
all eligible to membership in the
clubs, and need not try out for
either team in order to partake of
the other benefits of membership.
Any student may, upon payment of
the regular dues, receive a membership card which will admit him to
all the concerts of the season and
entitle him to a share in the division
of the balance in the treasury at the
end of the year.

The second in the series of lectures given under the joint auspices
of the University, the Woman's
Civic League and the Municipal
Art Society was delivered last
Thursday afternoon in the Academy of Music. The speaker was Dr.
Frederick Howe, Commissioner of
Immigration of New York, whose
subject was "The Incoming Alien:
A Problem and a Program." Dr.
Howe has made a special study of
municipal government both in this
country and abroad and has given
especially close attention to the immigrant as a factor in city life. He
is a graduate of Hopkins, his thesis
being "A Study of Internal Revenue Taxation in the United States."
After leaving Baltimore, he studied
and practiced law in both New
York and Cleveland. Dr. Howe has
written for the magazines and has
published a number of books—the
best known being "The City: The
Hope of Democracy."
According to Dr. Howe, just
what problems of immigration this
country will have to face no man
knows. "There may be very little
immigration after the war; there
may be a great deal. Opinions differ. European countries may close
the doors to the outgoing alien, for
he will be badly needed at home in
the work of reconstruction; or they
may encourage the emigration of
women and children and the wreckage of the war. Emigration to
America will depend upon the economic conditions in Europe on the
one hand and in America on the,
other." Then discussing the necessary assimilation of the foreigner,
he said: -As to whether immigration is a problem or not depends
upon our attitude toward it. If we
exert ourselves to protect the immigrant, to educate and assimilate him,
to find him employment, especially
to place him upon the land, the
melting-pot of America will assimilate him in the future as it has in
the past.-

The University Young Men's
Christian *Association gave a luncheon in Levering Hall on Friday to
the students of the University. Mr.
C. D. Hursey, who is the Young
Men's Christian Association Secretary on Friendly Relations Among
Foreign Students, delivered an excellent address to a large number
of students.
The attendance was very gratifying to the officers of the Association and was doubtless responsible
in a large measure for the announcement that such a luncheon
will probably be given every month.
The Association feels that such
meetings should serve a very worthy
purpose, in that not only a muchneeded social gathering is afforded
to the students, but an opportunity
is also given to hear attractive and
helpful talks by prominent men interested in the Young Men's Christian Association work at large.
Chapel services, which were held
last week under the leadership of
Dr. Elbert Russell, were unusually
well attended. Dr. Russell, who is
a member of the faculty of the University, gave some very inspiring
talks. The services this week are
being led by 'Air. Eugene Levering,
the president of the National Bank
of Commerce of this city. The
officers of the Association anticipate
an attendance which will surpass
all previous figures. This assumption does not seem at all unreasonable when it is remembered that
AiIr. Levering has always displayed
an active and never-failing interest
in the affairs of the University. He
is a very interesting speaker and it
is expected that every student will
want to hear and express his appreciation to the man who erected the
building which now bears his name
and from which the students derive
so many benefits.
The various Bible study classes
have been holding their weekly
meetings and the work is progressing rapidly. Both the enrollment
and attendance at these classes have
been abnormally large this year.
This fact is the source of great encouragement to the officers of the
Association. However, they wish
to announce that it is not too late
yet to enroll in any one of the four
classes. All students who desire to
enroll are requested to leave their
names at the secretary's office in
Levering Hall, where any further
information may be obtained.

Will Visit Hopkins.

Dr. Seichu Kinoshita, of the Imperial University, Tokio, Japan, is
a guest at the Hotel Stafford.
Dr. Kinoshita, who is in this country studying the educational systems in vogue, has come to Baltimore to visit the Johns Hopkins
University.
"So far I have visited only the
universities in New York and Boston," said Dr. Kinoshita, "and from
the limited observations that I have
made I think the United States is
leading the world in education.
"My relations with the American
people have been most pleasant. In
New York recently the Japanese
celebrated the coronation of the Emperor of Japan. I was present at a

dinner given at the Waldorf-Astoria
Hotel. It was a most interesting
event."
When asked to what extent Japan
was assisting Russia in the present
war, Dr. Kinoshita said that he
knew very little of the political
policy of his country and so could
not discuss it.

Mr. Kistler to Eorm Dancing Class.

A dancing class will be formed
this year under the direction of Mr.
T. E. Kistler, instructor in gymnasium work. The class will organize along lines similar to those followed by Mr. Kistler with his class
last year.
All students who are desirous of
receiving instruction in dancing
should see Mr. Kistler at once.
The fee will not be large and the
course will include several dances.
Mr. Kistler's success with his class
last year should insure a large enrollment of men this year, and since
it is planned to interest as many students as possible, this season's work
should be even better than that of
last year.

AT OTHER COLLEGES

New stands, which it is estimated
will accommodate 17,000 more spectators at the approaching HarvardYale football game, are being erected at the Harvard stadium. At the
completion of the stands, the total
seating capacity of the stadium will
be 39,000.
* * *,
A major of the field artillery was
ordered recently by the War Department to go to New Haven to
aid Yale in organizing and drilling
an artillery corps. The student
body requested that the War Department aid in such a plan.
* * *
The trustees of Kenyon College
have issued an order forbidding the
playing of tennis or golf on Sunday.
* * *
Carnegie Institute of Technology
has forbidden the sale of candy or
tobacco or both by students in any
of the buildings on the campus.
* * *
The University of Pennsylvania
and the city of Philadelphia are
jointly planning to build a new stadium to be used by both.
* * *
Dartmouth may become a coeducational institution before many
years. A certain benefactor, it is
said, has offered to provide the
money for several dormitories on
condition that Dartmouth be open
to women as well as men.
* * *
Ohio State University plans to
use a series of motion pictures
taken on the campus during 1915
commencement week to advertise
the college throughout the State.
* * *
Mark Payne, a Dakota Wesleyan
halfback, broke a record that has
stood for seventeen years by dropping one over from the 63-yard line.
The former record was sixty-two
yards.
* * *
The Leland. Stanford University
has purchased the 4,000 book collection of Dr. Ewald Flugel, the
well-known English philologist who
died last year.
* * *
Unless money is shortly forthcoming, the Syracuse crew, which
always makes a good showing at
the Poughkeepsie meet, will not
start next spring. An attempt will
be made to assess each student
$2.50.
* * *
The American Bankers' Association has opened a bank entirely under student management at Wesleyan University. If successful,
they will spread their idea to other
colleges and universities.
* * *
Stevens is erecting a new gymnasium on their campus. The building, two stories high, is of .elliptical
shape, a distinct departure from
the customary type and a decided
advance in gymnasium construction.

Too Literal.
One day a man who was interested in social work went into the
tenement district and, wishing to
see a certain man, but having only
a general idea as to where he lived,
approached a small boy.
"My boy," he asked, "can you
show me where M. Schmidowitz
lives?"
"Yes, sir. Come right with me,
sir."
The boy entered an adjacent
doorway and started to climb the
difficult stair. Up four flights he
went, the visitor breathlessly following, and finally paused at an
open door.
"This is the floor, sir," said the
boy. • "Mr. Schmidowitz lives in
nere."
"Looks as if we had stacked up
against hard luck," remarked the
visitor, peering into the room.
"Mr. Schmidowitz doesn't appear
tq he here."
No, sir," was the rejoinder.
"That was him sittin' down on the
front doorstep when we came in."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 15, 1915.

6
ROOTERS' IRISH SONG
[The following song, which was written
by an alumnus, will be given a trial by
the students at an early opportunity.
It is sung to especially written music,
which will be taught the rooters at the
next mass-meeting. In order to present
it to the students, it has been thought
advisable to publish it here.—ED.]

CHORUS:
And it's rah! rah! rah! rah! for Johns
Hopkins,
And a ray! ray! ray! ray! for ourselves,
And a Hoo! rah! rah! Hoo! for the
ladies
(Which, sweethearts, is meanin' yourselves.)
And here's to the team that we're beatin',
We hope they won't die with dismay,
For we're feelin' so strong and so
husky,
That we've got to lick someone today.
I.
So, boys, watch the ball that you're
rushin',
And play without favor or fear.
If you find it's your feet that you're
losin',
Just take a long slide on your ear.
When the rush line is limpin' in centre
And noses are gory and red,
Just butt with the place that's the hardest,
That's Irish for "usin' your head."
When the crowd has piled up on your
wind-shield
And the air is knocked out of your
frame,
Just crawl on your feet and go to it;
It's all in the luck of the game.
Don't kill a poor fellow that's dying,
Don't hit one that doesn't resist,
For football was made for the Irish,
To let off the steam from their chist.

Here's a health to you, Johns Hopkins;
Here's a health to you, old boy.
When the football teams are fighting
And the rooters root with joy,
May the score be ever with us,
May we win this game today.
Here's a cheer for all good sportsmen,
Are you ready, boys? Hooray!
IV.
When the fight grows fast and glorious,
When we strive with all our might,
It's good to be victorious,
But it's better still to fight.
So, here's to those that conquer
And to those who lose today;
And here's to dear old Hopkins,
Are you ready, boys? Hooray!
Adams to Meet Georgetown.

At a meeting of the Adams Literary Society last Thursday afternoon the possibility of entering into
several new debating alliances was
dis,cussed, and a team was chosen
to represent the Adams against
Georgetown University in a debate
to be held in the near future. The
speakers on the Hopkins team will
be A. A. Steinbach, R. Oppenheimer
and T. J. Tingley, while Fader and
Conn will act as alternate and adviser, respectively.
The debate will be held in Washington, while another Adams team
will go to Philadelphia this year to
meet representatives of the University of Pennsylvania. The subject
for the Georgetown debate is to be
decided upon by the Washington institution, while the Hopkins team
will be given its choice of sides.

DR. WOOD TO RETURN NOV. 25
FROM WORK IN CALIFORNIA

Dr. Robert W. Wood, who has
been taking photographs of the
moon at the Mount Wilson Observatory near Pasadena, Cal., will
return to the University on or about
November 25.
The definite object and purpose
of Dr. Wood's trip is to try to learn
what the surface of the moon is.
He said, before leaving, that he
thought he could accomplish his
aim by the use of the ultra-violet
rays (invisible light) for photographing.
Just how successful the photographs have been and what new
discoveries have been made will be
learned in the near future. However, it is reasonable to believe that
Dr. Wood will have some highly interesting and possibly wonderful
discoveries to present to the University.

High Honor to Alumnus at Oxford.
To the Editor of TH4 NEws-LtrrER:

Sir—I feel sure that all connected with the Johns Hopkins University will be glad to learn, if they
have not already done so, of a great
honor that has come to a former
member of the University. It came
too late to be announced in THE
NEWS-LITTER last year, and there
may be quite a number of people
who have not yet heard of it, for I
have not heard of its having been
published in any of the daily papers.
I therefore ask you for space
enough to say that Mr. Emory H.
Niles, A. B. '13, senior Maryland
Rhodes scholar at Oxford, England.
was awarded a "first class" in the
Oxford Law Schools last June, the
highest mark to which it is possible for him to attain. This was all
the more remarkable in view of the
fact that this distinction was attained after only two years at Oxford. Mr. Niles is planning to take
the B. C. L. degree after his third
year's work and I feel sure that his
friends at Hopkins will be glad to
know of his success in the past and
to wish him a continuance of it in
the future.
CARL, J. WEBER, A. B. '14.
Queen's College, Oxford, England.
October 24, 1915.

When Math. Meets Math.

Delterex Versine, the calculus
fiend, secanted into Le'vitt and
Pierce to sign on for the chess
tournament.
"Fifty cents, please !" said the
man behind the counter.
There was a geometric silence.
Delterex was differentiating his
next coop and other dividends. But
he suspected a plot, for his points
were all imaginary; and he had mislaid the natural log of his charge
number.
"My ambition has cancelled out,"
he cried as he gave the book a
square root. "Isn't that the limit?"
He is now approaching zero.—

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 15, 1915.

LAIR
PRICE, FIVE CENTS

HOPKINS LOSES TO HAVERFORD

UNIVERSITY TO MOVE THIS YEAR

ROOTERS TO MARCH IN PARADE 'VARSITY SUFFERS HARD LUCK

Pennsylvania Team Score Two Touchdowns and Win, 14 to 10—Brooks
and Hoffman Again the Stars.

All Departments, Excepting Chemistry,
to Take Up New Quarters at Homewood in October Plans Now
Complete.

Students and Alumni to March to Homewood Saturday—Full Band and
Special Decorations to Be
in Evidence.

Poor Officials at Haverford Largely Responsible for Loss of Game—Teams
Evenly Matched—Tackling and
Interference Improves.

It was definitely announced last
week that Johns Hopkins would be
at Homewood next fall. At present
it is not known whether the actual
moving will take place before or
after the session of the summer
school, but in all probability the
classes in the summer school will
be held in McCoy Hall.
All the departments, with the exception of that of chemistry, will
be at Homewood by October, 1916.
All plans for the chemical laboratory are complete, but the University has not the money at present
to erect a building as expensive as
the proposed laboratory. Estimates
were called for on this building, and
the bid most seriously considered
was for a $300,000 structure, but
last Monday it was learned that
the University had not accepted this
bid.
As the plans now stand, Gilman
Hall will house all the departments
that are now in McCoy Hall, and,
in addition, the biology laboratory
and the psychology department.
Biology will occupy a large part of
the basement of Gilman Hall, and
psychology will have the top floor.
The present Engineering Building will contain the electrical and
mechanical engineering departments
and also the physical laboratory.
Civil engineering, now in the Engineering Building, will, by next
fall, have a building of its own.
Work has been actively started on
the new home of the civil engineers. The new Civil Engineering
Building will also have the geology
laboratory until this department
gets a building of its own.
It would be impossible to move
the chemistry laboratory into any
of the other buildings at Homewood: so much special apparatus is
required that the proposition would
be exceedingly expensive. About
one-third of the expense of a new
chemistry building would be put
into specially constructed apparatus
and fixtures. Dr. A. R. L. Dohme
has offered, if several others will
assist him, to underwrite the interest for five years on a loan for the
erection of a new chemistry laboratory, but as yet no others have
shown an inclination to help Dr.
Dohme in his generous offer.
President Goodnow has talked
with Mayor Preston concerning the
purchase by the city of McCoy Hall
and the geological, chemical and
biological laboratories as an addition to the overcrowded City College. If the-University makes such
a sale the present physical laboratory will be used for a chemistry la-

For the first time since the memorable season of 1912, a monster
parade of the undergraduate students will be held before the football game with St. John's. The students will form in regular order,
according to classes, at McCoy Hall
on Saturday at 1.30 P. M., and
will proceed according to plans
which have not as yet been announced to the athletic field at
Homewood.
An effort will be made to obtain
permission from the city authorities
to have a steam roller at the head
of the procession and it is planned
to have a goat, suitably decorated,
to accompany the leaders of the
parade. The students will wear
regulation caps, in black and blue,
which will be obtainable from the
Athletic Association before the day
of the game. A full band will play
at the head of the parade during
the entire march. Class flags, alumni banners and all manner of decoration will be in evidence and no
effort will be spared to make the
effect as complete as possible.
A canvass of the entire University is being made to secure funds
to pay for the band and every student is expected to contribute fifty
cents. Representative members of
the four classes have been appointed
to collect the money, and all students are urged to hand in their
contributions as soon as possible, in
order to facilitate the work of the
committees.
Since the time of the game has
been set at 2.30 P. M., it has been
thought advisable to start the93,arade
at least an hour before that time,
in order to allow plenty of time for
an adequate demonstration. Participants are especially requested to
be on hand at least fifteen minutes
ahead of time, so that all arrangements may be successfully carried
out.

By COACH CHARLES E. BRICKLEY

The Black and Blue eleven met
defeat in its game with Haverford
Saturday, the score being 14 to 10.
Hopkins started by playing the
Pennsylvanians off their feet during the first quarter and scored ten
Points, but the enemy came back in
the latter part of the contest, holding the 'Varsity scoreless and gaining two touchdowns.
After the first kick-off, punts
were exchanged, and Hoffman and
Brooks carried the ball in a series
of runs to the 5-yard line, from
Which point Brooks carried it over
after three attempts through Haverford's line. Wilkinson kicked goal.
Brooks again figured in the scoring in this quarter, carrying the ball
on a 45-yard run to the 30-yard line,
from which Hoffman kicked goal.
There was no more scoring in the
quarter.
In the second period Haverford,
having the wind at its back, got the
better of the punting and scored a
touchdown from an on-side kick.
A disagreement arose as to the
validity of the play which .resulted
in this score. It was contended by
the Black and Blue that the backfield was off-side at the time of the
kick and was hence ineligible to recover the ball. However, the officials allowed the touchdown to
count. The Hopkins men allowed
the ball to roll, without touching it,
over the goal for what they believed
was a touchback, and were very
much disappointed to find that the
officials decided to allow the score
to count.
In the remainder of the first half
little was gained by either side.
Bowers ran a punt through a broken
field in a
hair-raising manner for
thirty-five yards, but the ball was
called back by the officials, who penalized the Black and Blue for holding. No more scoring was done in
this period.
In the next period, Haverford „
started out with different tactics,
using the forward pass to advantage
for a while,
but finally resorting to
kicking after Hopkins had broken
Up several
plays, and Darley
dropped a
punt on the 8-yard line
Which was recovered by Van Dam
and carried over
for Haverford's
second touchdown.
The fourth quarter brought forth
no especial gain for either side.
Forward passing was used throughout the period, but the ball remained
about in midfield most of the time.
The stars of the game were Hoffman and Brooks for Hopkins and
Van Dam and Moon for Haverford.
Schmidt and Ormond also excelled
(C9ntinued on page 8, col.- 2)

The game with Haverford was a
heart-breaking affair, both, from the
standpoint of the players and
coaches. The teams were evenly
matched, and the contest would
have been a wonder to watch had it
not been for the poor work of the
officials.
Never in all my experience in
football have I seen a game conducted as poorly as on Saturday.
And the unfortunate part of it all
was that the great majority of the
poor decisions counted against Hopkins—one of them resulting directly
in a touchdown on a so-called onside kick. The referee in particular was at fault time and again, and
it always seemed that Hopkins was
the team to suffer. There is certainly no disgrace in losing a football game to a team which plays
better football, and I should have
nothing but praise for our opponents if they outplayed us and won,
but I really feel that if the officials
had given us half a chance we
would have come out on top.
One of the most gratifying features of the game, from the coaches'
standpoint, was the improvement in
interference on the part of Hopkins.
For the first time this season opponents were really taken out of
the play. But even a greater improvement must be made if we are
to defeat St. John's and Maryland
Agricultural College.
The tackling on the part of Hopkins was very good. The men
tackled hard and clean, and there
were few missed tackles. The work
of the secondary defense was especially good in this respect. Haverford had a varied open attack which
was not easy to solve.

all went to Haverford. Credit
should be given to them for taking
advantage of them. Hopkins is still

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 15, 1915.

MUSICIANS' WORK PROGRESSES

DR. HOWE ON "INCOMING ALIEN"

Y. M. C. A. OUTLOOK BRILLIANT

Glee and Instrumental Men Hard at
Work on Season's Music—Attractive Schedule Being Arranged.
More Men Needed.

New York Commissioner of Immigration
Says Number of Incoming Aliens
to Be Expected After War
is Uncertain.

Attendance at Chapel and Bible Classes
Improves Greatly - Mr. Hursey
Speaks at Luncheon— Officers
Pleased With Prospects.

The Musical Clubs have gotten
their work on the program for this
year under headway and are well
on the road to what will undoubtedly be a most successful concert season. The Glee Club has had several rehearsals, and although the attendance at some was not encouraging, those last held were as successful as the usual run of beginning
meetings. A large number of new
men are out for the club, and from
now on the work of the leader will
consist largely of picking out the
most likely candidates. All students who have in mind trying out
for the club should report at once,
while there is yet an opportunity
to catch up with the work.
The Instrumental Club began its
work with a good rehearsal on Friday night. The men from last
year's clubs were out in full force,
but few new candidates presented
themselves. The management desires to announce that since the
work of the Instrumental Club goes
along very rapidly, all candidates
who have not as yet reported should
do so at the next rehearsal, in order
to get in line before it becomes too
late. Flute, 'cello and clarinet players are especially needed.
Plans for a very full schedule are
being worked out by the management. The season will begin with
the first week in January and will
extend to the week after Easter,
taking in a large number of engagements in and about Baltimore, as
well as two or three trips of moderate length. Attention is again being called to the fact that outside
assistance in the work of arranging
trips is desired by the management,
and that five dollars will be paid
any student who works up acceptable plans for a trip.
The annual McCoy Hall concert
will be held in the latter part of
February. The exact date has not
yet been set, but will be chosen from
the latter two Friday nights—the
eighteenth and the twenty-fifth.
Especial attention will be paid the
work on this concert, and a particular effort will be made to enlist the
support of the undergraduates and
alumni to a greater degree than has
been attained in former years.
The management wishes to call
the attention of the undergraduate
students to the fact that they are
all eligible to membership in the
clubs, and need not try out for
either team in order to partake of
the other benefits of membership.
Any student may, upon payment of
the regular dues, receive a membership card which will admit him to
all the concerts of the season and
entitle him to a share in the division
of the balance in the treasury at the
end of the year.

The second in the series of lectures given under the joint auspices
of the University, the Woman's
Civic League and the Municipal
Art Society was delivered last
Thursday afternoon in the Academy of Music. The speaker was Dr.
Frederick Howe, Commissioner of
Immigration of New York, whose
subject was "The Incoming Alien:
A Problem and a Program." Dr.
Howe has made a special study of
municipal government both in this
country and abroad and has given
especially close attention to the immigrant as a factor in city life. He
is a graduate of Hopkins, his thesis
being "A Study of Internal Revenue Taxation in the United States."
After leaving Baltimore, he studied
and practiced law in both New
York and Cleveland. Dr. Howe has
written for the magazines and has
published a number of books—the
best known being "The City: The
Hope of Democracy."
According to Dr. Howe, just
what problems of immigration this
country will have to face no man
knows. "There may be very little
immigration after the war; there
may be a great deal. Opinions differ. European countries may close
the doors to the outgoing alien, for
he will be badly needed at home in
the work of reconstruction; or they
may encourage the emigration of
women and children and the wreckage of the war. Emigration to
America will depend upon the economic conditions in Europe on the
one hand and in America on the,
other." Then discussing the necessary assimilation of the foreigner,
he said: -As to whether immigration is a problem or not depends
upon our attitude toward it. If we
exert ourselves to protect the immigrant, to educate and assimilate him,
to find him employment, especially
to place him upon the land, the
melting-pot of America will assimilate him in the future as it has in
the past.-

The University Young Men's
Christian *Association gave a luncheon in Levering Hall on Friday to
the students of the University. Mr.
C. D. Hursey, who is the Young
Men's Christian Association Secretary on Friendly Relations Among
Foreign Students, delivered an excellent address to a large number
of students.
The attendance was very gratifying to the officers of the Association and was doubtless responsible
in a large measure for the announcement that such a luncheon
will probably be given every month.
The Association feels that such
meetings should serve a very worthy
purpose, in that not only a muchneeded social gathering is afforded
to the students, but an opportunity
is also given to hear attractive and
helpful talks by prominent men interested in the Young Men's Christian Association work at large.
Chapel services, which were held
last week under the leadership of
Dr. Elbert Russell, were unusually
well attended. Dr. Russell, who is
a member of the faculty of the University, gave some very inspiring
talks. The services this week are
being led by 'Air. Eugene Levering,
the president of the National Bank
of Commerce of this city. The
officers of the Association anticipate
an attendance which will surpass
all previous figures. This assumption does not seem at all unreasonable when it is remembered that
AiIr. Levering has always displayed
an active and never-failing interest
in the affairs of the University. He
is a very interesting speaker and it
is expected that every student will
want to hear and express his appreciation to the man who erected the
building which now bears his name
and from which the students derive
so many benefits.
The various Bible study classes
have been holding their weekly
meetings and the work is progressing rapidly. Both the enrollment
and attendance at these classes have
been abnormally large this year.
This fact is the source of great encouragement to the officers of the
Association. However, they wish
to announce that it is not too late
yet to enroll in any one of the four
classes. All students who desire to
enroll are requested to leave their
names at the secretary's office in
Levering Hall, where any further
information may be obtained.

Will Visit Hopkins.

Dr. Seichu Kinoshita, of the Imperial University, Tokio, Japan, is
a guest at the Hotel Stafford.
Dr. Kinoshita, who is in this country studying the educational systems in vogue, has come to Baltimore to visit the Johns Hopkins
University.
"So far I have visited only the
universities in New York and Boston," said Dr. Kinoshita, "and from
the limited observations that I have
made I think the United States is
leading the world in education.
"My relations with the American
people have been most pleasant. In
New York recently the Japanese
celebrated the coronation of the Emperor of Japan. I was present at a

dinner given at the Waldorf-Astoria
Hotel. It was a most interesting
event."
When asked to what extent Japan
was assisting Russia in the present
war, Dr. Kinoshita said that he
knew very little of the political
policy of his country and so could
not discuss it.

Mr. Kistler to Eorm Dancing Class.

A dancing class will be formed
this year under the direction of Mr.
T. E. Kistler, instructor in gymnasium work. The class will organize along lines similar to those followed by Mr. Kistler with his class
last year.
All students who are desirous of
receiving instruction in dancing
should see Mr. Kistler at once.
The fee will not be large and the
course will include several dances.
Mr. Kistler's success with his class
last year should insure a large enrollment of men this year, and since
it is planned to interest as many students as possible, this season's work
should be even better than that of
last year.

AT OTHER COLLEGES

New stands, which it is estimated
will accommodate 17,000 more spectators at the approaching HarvardYale football game, are being erected at the Harvard stadium. At the
completion of the stands, the total
seating capacity of the stadium will
be 39,000.
* * *,
A major of the field artillery was
ordered recently by the War Department to go to New Haven to
aid Yale in organizing and drilling
an artillery corps. The student
body requested that the War Department aid in such a plan.
* * *
The trustees of Kenyon College
have issued an order forbidding the
playing of tennis or golf on Sunday.
* * *
Carnegie Institute of Technology
has forbidden the sale of candy or
tobacco or both by students in any
of the buildings on the campus.
* * *
The University of Pennsylvania
and the city of Philadelphia are
jointly planning to build a new stadium to be used by both.
* * *
Dartmouth may become a coeducational institution before many
years. A certain benefactor, it is
said, has offered to provide the
money for several dormitories on
condition that Dartmouth be open
to women as well as men.
* * *
Ohio State University plans to
use a series of motion pictures
taken on the campus during 1915
commencement week to advertise
the college throughout the State.
* * *
Mark Payne, a Dakota Wesleyan
halfback, broke a record that has
stood for seventeen years by dropping one over from the 63-yard line.
The former record was sixty-two
yards.
* * *
The Leland. Stanford University
has purchased the 4,000 book collection of Dr. Ewald Flugel, the
well-known English philologist who
died last year.
* * *
Unless money is shortly forthcoming, the Syracuse crew, which
always makes a good showing at
the Poughkeepsie meet, will not
start next spring. An attempt will
be made to assess each student
$2.50.
* * *
The American Bankers' Association has opened a bank entirely under student management at Wesleyan University. If successful,
they will spread their idea to other
colleges and universities.
* * *
Stevens is erecting a new gymnasium on their campus. The building, two stories high, is of .elliptical
shape, a distinct departure from
the customary type and a decided
advance in gymnasium construction.

Too Literal.
One day a man who was interested in social work went into the
tenement district and, wishing to
see a certain man, but having only
a general idea as to where he lived,
approached a small boy.
"My boy," he asked, "can you
show me where M. Schmidowitz
lives?"
"Yes, sir. Come right with me,
sir."
The boy entered an adjacent
doorway and started to climb the
difficult stair. Up four flights he
went, the visitor breathlessly following, and finally paused at an
open door.
"This is the floor, sir," said the
boy. • "Mr. Schmidowitz lives in
nere."
"Looks as if we had stacked up
against hard luck," remarked the
visitor, peering into the room.
"Mr. Schmidowitz doesn't appear
tq he here."
No, sir," was the rejoinder.
"That was him sittin' down on the
front doorstep when we came in."

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 15, 1915.

6
ROOTERS' IRISH SONG
[The following song, which was written
by an alumnus, will be given a trial by
the students at an early opportunity.
It is sung to especially written music,
which will be taught the rooters at the
next mass-meeting. In order to present
it to the students, it has been thought
advisable to publish it here.—ED.]

CHORUS:
And it's rah! rah! rah! rah! for Johns
Hopkins,
And a ray! ray! ray! ray! for ourselves,
And a Hoo! rah! rah! Hoo! for the
ladies
(Which, sweethearts, is meanin' yourselves.)
And here's to the team that we're beatin',
We hope they won't die with dismay,
For we're feelin' so strong and so
husky,
That we've got to lick someone today.
I.
So, boys, watch the ball that you're
rushin',
And play without favor or fear.
If you find it's your feet that you're
losin',
Just take a long slide on your ear.
When the rush line is limpin' in centre
And noses are gory and red,
Just butt with the place that's the hardest,
That's Irish for "usin' your head."
When the crowd has piled up on your
wind-shield
And the air is knocked out of your
frame,
Just crawl on your feet and go to it;
It's all in the luck of the game.
Don't kill a poor fellow that's dying,
Don't hit one that doesn't resist,
For football was made for the Irish,
To let off the steam from their chist.

Here's a health to you, Johns Hopkins;
Here's a health to you, old boy.
When the football teams are fighting
And the rooters root with joy,
May the score be ever with us,
May we win this game today.
Here's a cheer for all good sportsmen,
Are you ready, boys? Hooray!
IV.
When the fight grows fast and glorious,
When we strive with all our might,
It's good to be victorious,
But it's better still to fight.
So, here's to those that conquer
And to those who lose today;
And here's to dear old Hopkins,
Are you ready, boys? Hooray!
Adams to Meet Georgetown.

At a meeting of the Adams Literary Society last Thursday afternoon the possibility of entering into
several new debating alliances was
dis,cussed, and a team was chosen
to represent the Adams against
Georgetown University in a debate
to be held in the near future. The
speakers on the Hopkins team will
be A. A. Steinbach, R. Oppenheimer
and T. J. Tingley, while Fader and
Conn will act as alternate and adviser, respectively.
The debate will be held in Washington, while another Adams team
will go to Philadelphia this year to
meet representatives of the University of Pennsylvania. The subject
for the Georgetown debate is to be
decided upon by the Washington institution, while the Hopkins team
will be given its choice of sides.

DR. WOOD TO RETURN NOV. 25
FROM WORK IN CALIFORNIA

Dr. Robert W. Wood, who has
been taking photographs of the
moon at the Mount Wilson Observatory near Pasadena, Cal., will
return to the University on or about
November 25.
The definite object and purpose
of Dr. Wood's trip is to try to learn
what the surface of the moon is.
He said, before leaving, that he
thought he could accomplish his
aim by the use of the ultra-violet
rays (invisible light) for photographing.
Just how successful the photographs have been and what new
discoveries have been made will be
learned in the near future. However, it is reasonable to believe that
Dr. Wood will have some highly interesting and possibly wonderful
discoveries to present to the University.

High Honor to Alumnus at Oxford.
To the Editor of TH4 NEws-LtrrER:

Sir—I feel sure that all connected with the Johns Hopkins University will be glad to learn, if they
have not already done so, of a great
honor that has come to a former
member of the University. It came
too late to be announced in THE
NEWS-LITTER last year, and there
may be quite a number of people
who have not yet heard of it, for I
have not heard of its having been
published in any of the daily papers.
I therefore ask you for space
enough to say that Mr. Emory H.
Niles, A. B. '13, senior Maryland
Rhodes scholar at Oxford, England.
was awarded a "first class" in the
Oxford Law Schools last June, the
highest mark to which it is possible for him to attain. This was all
the more remarkable in view of the
fact that this distinction was attained after only two years at Oxford. Mr. Niles is planning to take
the B. C. L. degree after his third
year's work and I feel sure that his
friends at Hopkins will be glad to
know of his success in the past and
to wish him a continuance of it in
the future.
CARL, J. WEBER, A. B. '14.
Queen's College, Oxford, England.
October 24, 1915.

When Math. Meets Math.

Delterex Versine, the calculus
fiend, secanted into Le'vitt and
Pierce to sign on for the chess
tournament.
"Fifty cents, please !" said the
man behind the counter.
There was a geometric silence.
Delterex was differentiating his
next coop and other dividends. But
he suspected a plot, for his points
were all imaginary; and he had mislaid the natural log of his charge
number.
"My ambition has cancelled out,"
he cried as he gave the book a
square root. "Isn't that the limit?"
He is now approaching zero.—
Lampoon.
